revision.comment: /* Growing beyond the book format */ new section
revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages|quality=FB}}
== Thank you! ==
Thanks for featuring this book. I apologise for not having had time to continue working on it for a long time but it is certainly very satisfying to see this recognition all the same. I hope my contribution is helpful to others as an example of some of the things that can be done. Although I haven't been able to do any more work on Miskito, more recently I have developed a language course for the Central American language Nawat (aka Pipil) on Facebook, and anyone interested is invited to take a look by adding Timumachtikan Nawat as a friend, or else visit the FB group Salvemos el idioma nahuat. Thank you again, Alan --[[User:A R King|A R King]] ([[User talk:A R King|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/A R King|contribs]]) 09:08, 27 August 2011 (UTC)
== Growing beyond the book format ==
My name is Ian and I'm from a project called Wikiotics, where we build free software tools for language instruction. We are starting to build collections of interactive language lessons that can serve as textbook replacements for students and this wikibook seems like a great place to start.
If there is anyone here who is interested in expanding this content beyond a traditional text-based book format or who would like to incorporate interactive lessons we build based on the outline of this book, just chime in here or contact us at contact AT wikiotics DOT org or in irc at #wikiotics on freenode.
As example of the kind of new materials you can make with our tools, here are examples our current lesson types: * Picture choice lesson (http://wikiotics.org/en/Introduction), * Re-mixable Podcast (http://wikiotics.org/user/ian/FSI-Mandarin-Module01-Unit01), * Text multiple choice lesson (http://wikiotics.org/en/WANY_Hospital_grammar) * new Storybook lesson [''coming soon''](http://laurent.dev.wikiotics.net/en/storybook1).
[[User:Wikiotics|Wikiotics]] ([[User talk:Wikiotics|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Wikiotics|contribs]]) 15:52, 13 June 2012 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
== Alternative/Regional Spelling variances ==
I personally found that the Mohawk language Phrases listed are not accurate as far as the teachings I have received. Nor do they match what I have found on sites I have been directed to by my community in this area. I am not an expert and am still new in my learning of my heritage. Therefore still learning and do not know about such things as regional diversity of the language etc. Which may play a large part in it since some of the words were similar an example is
Hi you have listed as "Khwe" I learned as "Kwe"
Thank You is the same both list "Nia:wen" as the appropriate spelling.
So any differences may be just regional variances on a common super structure. And I am wondering if perhaps either refining the page listing to the geographical area it is from or listing the different versions might be appropriate.
One of the online resources I use when I can not immediately reach those I learn from is http://www.kahonwes.com/language/mohawk_words.htm perhaps it might shed some light.[[User:Michaelmarlin|Michaelmarlin]] ([[User talk:Michaelmarlin|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Michaelmarlin|contribs]]) 08:08, 15 January 2013 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}} Below are some public domain resources we can exploit to make this book better. There are some that are really old, and are probably only semi-useful because the writing system is different, but the US government has published a lot of resources, including phrase books, dictionaries, and readers that are now pubic domain. Below is a collection of useful links: *Grammar/Dictionary [http://archive.org/details/TheNavahoLanguage The Navaho language] *Phrasebook Talking Navajo Before You Know It (http://archive.org/details/TalkingNavajoBeforeYouKnowIt) *Readers: The Flag of My Country (http://archive.org/details/theflagofmycount23424gut)
Little Man's Family (http://www.gutenberg.org/files/37829/37829-h/37829-h.htm) *Wikipedia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navajo language
http://nv.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%8Diyis%C3%AD%C3%AD_Naaltsoos

revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages}}
== hare/jackrabbit and rabbit/bunny ==
There was a slight mistake in the text that I took liberty to correct. Otherwise, nice work:). Just like in USA, where people often use the name rabbit for hare, here in Croatia a lot of people do not know the difference between rabbit and hare and they use the name zec (hare) for both. So the most of people wouldn't notice the difference, but it's good to know right names for both animals anyway:).
'''The European hare (Lepus europaeus)''', also known as the brown hare, is a species of hare native to Europe and western Asia / '''Europski zec ili obični zec (Lepus europaeus)''' je vrsta zeca autohtona u Europi i zapadnoj Aziji. Nije glodavac već dvojezubac prilagođen otvorenim krajevima umjerene klime.
'''The European rabbit or common rabbit (Oryctolagus cuniculus)''' is a species of rabbit native to southwestern Europe (Spain and Portugal) and northwest Africa (Morocco and Algeria)./ '''Patuljasti kunić je vrsta domesticiranog europskog kunića (Oryctolagus cuniculus)'''.
(source, Wikipedia, English and Croatian
Greetings from Zagreb
[[User:Peregrin Falcon|Peregrin Falcon]] ([[User talk:Peregrin Falcon|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Peregrin Falcon|contribs]]) 19:53, 26 August 2013 (UTC)
== Zamorac/zamorčić ==
Problem with these two words (zamorac and zamorčić) are simillar to problems connected to words zec and kunić (hare and rabbit). Just as common people use name zec for both, hare (zec) and rabbit (kunić) they also use name zamorac for guinea pig and Cercopithecus monkeys, but scientists (biologists and veterinarians) and lawmakers use name zamorčić for guinea pig and zamorac for Cercopithecus monkeys.
Here are examples of texts written by scientists and lawmakers (in Croatian):
zamorac ili zamorčić[uredi]
Moram napomenuti, iako se u narodu zamorčića često naziva zamorcem da se u stručnim krugovima zamorcima nazivaju samo majmnuni zamorci, dok je za male glodavce rezerviran isključivo naziv zamorčić kako bi se izbjeglo nepotrebno brkanje. Dakle situacija je ista kao kod kunića i zečeva gdje se, u narodu, i kunići i zečevi nazivaju zečevima, ali u stručnim tekstovima se to nikada ne miješa. Dakle, zato sam ispod dao navode s poveznicama na tekstove stručnjaka (veterinara i sl.) i zakone i propise u kojima se spominju zamorčići kako bi sve bilo jasnije. U članku nisam želio ništa dirati. Evo primjera: Zamorčić - pričljivi ljubimac Piše: Ana Shek-Vugrovečki, dr. vet. med., Zavod za fiziologiju i radiobiologiju, Veterinarski fakultet, ZagrebZamorčići (Caviidae), pripadaju redu glodavaca jer im glodnjaci i kutnjaci rastu cijeloga života. Na svijetu postoji osam vrsta zamorčića, ali gotovo svi koji se drže kao kućni ljubimci pripadaju vrsti Cavia porcellus. U prirodi žive u Južnoj Americi (Venezueli, Peruu, Brazilu...) u obiteljskim skupinama. U Europu je donesen prije otprilike četiristo godina i od tada se uzgoja kao kućni ljubimac i kao model za znanstvene svrhe. http://www.zdrav-zivot.com.hr/index.php?cat=zamorcic___pricljivi_ljubimac
zamorčić (Cavia), rod glodavaca iz por. → prasenaca; domaći z. (C. porcellus) pokusna je životinja u biol. i med. laboratorijima. http://www.znacenje.info/definicija/zamorcic.html
Veterinarske stanice Remetinec Zamorčići Kako se lista družbenih žvotinja povećava, tako su svoje mjesto među ljudima našli i zamorčići. Da, točan i pravilan naziv je ta umanjenica. Zamorac je jedna vrsta majmuna.. http://www.vsr.hr/zamorci.html
] NN 176/04 - Ministarstvo poljoprivrede zamorčić (Cavia porcellus). – zlatni hrčak (Mesocricetus auratus). – kunić (Oryctolagus cuniculus). – nečovjekoliki majmuni. – pas (Canis familiaris). – mačka ... https://www.google.hr/#fp=84ebe8440e7f696b&q=zamor%C4%8Di%C4%87&start=40
Veterinarska znanost i struka 2013. - VZS 2013. Cijena: 375,00 kn (PDV uračunat u cijenu) Službeni jezik radionice: Hrvatski Radionica 3: [PRIJAVA] Probavni sustav u glodavaca (kunić, činćila, zamorčić) www.vef.unizg.hr/vzs2013/radionice.htm‎
Savjeti veterinara - Veterinarska ambulanta VET - svijet - Google Sites Ako kunići, zamorčići i ostali glodavci nemaju mogućnost jesti cekotrope, tada će patiti od pothranjenosti. Većina glodavaca i dvojezubaca izbacuje cekotrope ... sites.google.com/site/vetsvijet/savjeti‎
47 26.04.2011 Pravilnik o zaštiti životinja koje se koriste u pokusima .. 11. 6. 2013. - OVOGA PRAVILNIKA. – miš (Mus musculus). – štakor (Rattus norvegicus). – zamorčić (Cavia porcellus). – zlatni hrčak (Mesocricetus auratus). neuron.mefst.hr/.../Pravilnik%20o%20zastiti%20zivotinja%2047_2011.p...‎
Hrvatski leksikon zamorčić (Cavia), rod glodavaca iz por. → prasenaca; domaći z. (C. porcellus) pokusna je životinja u biol. i med. laboratorijima. http://www.hrleksikon.info/definicija/zamorcic.html
PROLEKSIS ENCIKLOPEDIJA ZAMORCI Struka: BIOLOŠKE I MEDICINSKE ZNANOSTI I PODRUČJA zamorci (Cercopithecidae), por. uskonosih majmuna iz Afrike i Azije, duga repa, ličnih vrećica, zadnjičnih žuljeva. Trče na sve četiri noge, stupaju cijelim stopalom, kralježnica jednostavna. U z. se ubrajaju pravi z. (Cercopithecus), pavijani (Papio), sakati majmuni (Colubus)… Nastavi čitati → Objavljeno: Lipanj 2012. ZAMORČIĆI → PRASENCA Struka: BIOLOŠKE I MEDICINSKE ZNANOSTI I PODRUČJA zamorčići → prasenca http://proleksis.lzmk.hr/tag/bioloske-i-medicinske-znanosti-i-podrucja/page/338/ Objavljeno: Lipanj 2012.
Greetings from Zagreb, Croatia [[User:Peregrin Falcon|Peregrin Falcon]] ([[User talk:Peregrin Falcon|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Peregrin Falcon|contribs]]) 20:55, 26 August 2013 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
== VOCAB ==
Hi! Wouldn't it be great if we had lists of vocab to do with everyday life?
So, if you fancy reading a fitness magazine of an evening, you can just have that page open for the key terms.
Or if you know you have to go to a party, you can hold your own with small talk.
Plan to make lists for:- supermarket, government office, school, language school, outdoors, leisure, transport, socializing, seeing a doctor, computing, cycling, paying bills, sports, arts and crafts, politics, science etc [[User:Etellerandet|Etellerandet]] ([[User talk:Etellerandet|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Etellerandet|contribs]]) 12:48, 17 April 2012 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
Can you put in more examples, or a link to more conjugated verbs? There is less readily-available info on Danish than other languages.

{{WikiProject Languages}} ==Remarks== * "Hoe Nederlands leren met dit lesboek" is NOT correct Dutch (but a sort of translation ??) One could say: #. "Hoe Nederlands '''te''' leren met dit lesboek", somewhat old-fashioned, but OK or #. "Hoe kun je/kunt u Nederlands leren met dit boek" which is longish. #. "Hoe leert u Nederlands met dit lesboek" #. "Nederlands leren met dit lesboek"
I would pick 1.
Cheers, [[w:User:JMMuller]], Dutch wikipedian

{{WikiProject Languages}} ==Remark== * "Mevrouw De Vries: Zeer goed, dank u wel. En met u?"
'''<s>Zeer</s> goed''' is a bit old-fashioned (can it still be heard? It's ironical nowadays.) for '''Heel goed'''.
Regards, [[w:en:User:JMMuller]] (Dutch wikipedian)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==Remarks== "hij liep overal mee mee. (he went along with anything at all)
hij zat overal aan aan. (he was a high level social tiger)"
In practice, Dutch speakers try to avoid double prepositions, as they sound ugly and are confusing.
Regards, [[w:en:User:JMMuller]] (Dutch wikipedian)
**Again: stylistically you may have a point, but the point was to demonstrate that an adverb (not: preposition) like "mee" can have different origins. And no the sentences are not wrong. And no they are not always [http://www.michielb.nl/fotolog/2005/05/daar-gaan-wij-dus-mee-mee.html avoided] [[User:Jcwf|Jcwf]] ([[User talk:Jcwf|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Jcwf|contribs]]) 19:28, 4 December 2012 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==Remarks== * "fantastisch - fantastischer - meest fantastisch" does not sound well, in fact exaggerated, or it is meant ironically, because ''fantastisch'' is in itself a kind of superlative. Perhaps use e.g., ''lelijk'' etc. instead.
Regards, [[w:en:User:JMMuller]] Dutch wikipedian
**Wat een onzin: [http://www.elfvoetbal.nl/nieuws/172667_fa-cup-winst-zou-nog-fantastischer-zijn zie] [[User:Jcwf|Jcwf]] ([[User talk:Jcwf|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Jcwf|contribs]]) 19:32, 4 December 2012 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==Remarks== * ''<s>Jessicas</s>'' should be ''Jessica's'' * ''Het ligt dus voor de hand dat ze <s>het</s> daar heeft laten liggen.'' de portemonnee ==> '''hem''' (instead of ''het'', because the sentences are close together.
**De sentence right before it says "het geld".
Later on in the story, one might perhaps loosely refer to a wallet as a thing, ''het ding'' so ''het'' is used: ''Ik hoop dat <s>het</s> gevonden is'', although i would still say ''Ik hoop dat '''hij''' gevonden is''. Best to teach good Dutch.
**If you want to refer to the blond servant, sure, but not if she means the money. The guy would be "hij". People who learn Dutch should NOT refer to a wallet as "he", anymore than they do it English.
Regards, [[w:en:User:JMMuller]], Dutch wikipedian

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==Remarks== 1. "Daarvoor herinnerde hij zich te veel goede tijden met haar." sounds a bit strange (goede tijden = ''good times''?)
Daarvoor had hij te veel goede herinneringen aan haar?
**A bit strange? [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goede_Tijden,_Slechte_Tijden really?]
2.
"De kok schotelde de man een ovenschotel voor - The cook served the man an oven dish.
Door de kok werd aan de man een ovenschotel voorgeschoteld - An oven dish was served ..
De man kreeg een ovenschotel voorgeschoteld - The man got served ...."
are unfortunate examples, as the word "schotel" is used twice in each sentence: confusing.
**I'll change it
3. Opdat is strange here, '''dat''' seems better: "Opdat (?) hij lang moge leven" => "'''Dat''' hij lang moge leven = ''Dat hij lang leve'' = ''Hij leve lang'' (as in the song ''Lang zal hij/ze leven'')
4. "Ik doe het vet stollen." is correct Dutch, but somewhat bookish. People say: ''Ik '''laat''' het vet stollen.'' (verb ''laten'', let)
Regards, [[w:en:User:JMMuller]] Dutch wikipedian

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==Remark== "af en toe - occasionally, now and then" is not archaic, but daily Dutch. Regards, [[w:en:User:JMMuller]] Dutch wikipedian

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==Strange coffee== "Is er al koffie? Nee ik heb er nog geen gezet." is wrong. Should be: "Is er al koffie? Nee ik heb hem nog niet gezet" Some speakers (e.g., my mother) consider ''koffie'' female and would say: Nee, ik heb ze nog niet gezet"
Kind regards, [[w:en:User:JMMuller]] (Dutch wikipedian)
:You are from below the rivers, I am sure. In the north it is increasingly unusual to refer to an inanimate object with him, her etc. People ''avoid'' such references, because hem and haar are more reserved for ''persons''. One way to avoid the hij/zij/hem/haar reference is to use a pronominal adverb like ''er(van)'' and no there is nothing wrong about that. [[User:Jcwf|Jcwf]] ([[User talk:Jcwf|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Jcwf|contribs]]) 19:14, 4 December 2012 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==Remarks== 1 "Ja, ik heb dat zullen doen, maar ik had geen tijd meer. " sounds weird. Dutch speakers would say:
* "Ja, ik '''zou''' dat doen, maar ik had geen tijd meer. "
***I don't agree: your sentence does not reflect the perfect aspect: it means something else.
2 "waar ik het zou hebben kunnen laten verlengen." This is Dutch fun for cabaret! The word order is wrong: should be * "waar ik het zou '''kunnen hebben''' laten verlengen." but still it's too lengthy.
***Oh sure, lengthy strings of infinitves are stylistically undesirable. The point is to show that in Dutch they are '''possible'''. The word order is '''not''' wrong, just because it is not the order ''you'' normally use. The word order of modal verbs differs from region to region.
3. "Je zult" is somewhat Bible language/dialect/Flemish. Daily usage: "'''Jij/je zal'''", the standard, must not be omitted!!
***???? The standard is "je zult". "Je zal" is colloquial.... (And no I am not Flemish)
Kind regards, [[w:en:User:JMMuller]], Dutch wikipedian

{{WikiProject Languages}}
== Antwerp / Brabant ==
This seemes more like Antwerps or Brabants than common Flemish. Perhaps it's a good idea to say that the Flemish described here is mainly spoken in area 22 on the map. In the other regions (1, 23, 24) a lot of these things ar as unfamiliar as standard Dutch. Especially number 1 (West Flanders), number 24 (Limburg) and Gand (cappital of East Flanders, region 23) have very different dialects.
== Other personal pronouns == This para ended with the remark: ''"Note that "gijle" uses singular verb forms, while "wijle"/"zijle" uses plural verb forms, but all of them have plural meanings; <u> this phenomenon is also seen in German.</u>"''. I have deleted the underlined passage, because there is no German personal pronoun with "plural meaning" that uses a singular verb form. Clearly there has been some confusion about German verb forms, cf. the discussion on German Wikipedia under [https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benutzer_Diskussion:IP-Los#Wikibooks_on_Fl.C3.A4misch]. --[[Special:Contributions/91.2.116.77|91.2.116.77]] ([[User talk:91.2.116.77|discuss]]) 17:11, 26 December 2013 (UTC) = [https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benutzer:Zerolevel de.wikipedia/user:Zerolevel]

revision.comment: Is Cooked Pineapple As Good As Canned Pineapple To Be Used In "Jell-O"
revision.text: I already know that canned pineapple is safe to use with "Jello" recipes. The fruit is heated during the canning process which kills the enzyme that neutralizes the ability of the gellatin to jell up. With fresh pineapple, the gelatin process fails. What I want to know is: If I cook my fresh pineapple before using it in my gelatin recipe, would it yield the same results as with the canned pineapple? This possibility then begs the next question. At what tempurature do I cook the fresh pineapple; and for how long? Do I have to let the cooked pineapple cool overnight in the refrigerator before adding it to the gelatin mold? Can I put the cooked pineapple into the "Jello" recipe immediately while both are still warm? One interesting result yielded unexpected results. Instead of cutting into the pineapple right away, I let it sit out overnight on the kitchen for seven days. This allowed the fruit to ripen a bit more. It made the fruit to be much more sweeter on the inside. With it's reduced acidity, it did not caused my throat to get burned from the acidic acid. I have asthma, and the burning tissue in the throat always trips an asthma attack. As the pineapple was so extra sweet, no acidic juice came burning up my throat. I can now see myself buying more fresh pineapple. I have Central Air Conditioning; so the home is kept cool. I will let the pineapple sit at room temperature for one week...depending on the scent of the fruit. It will smell sweeter. Once the pineapple smells very sweet, I'm cut it up for snacking...as well as for making "Jello" recipes. While, I guess, I could just experiment and find out the hard way. But, I'd just as soon as, find out from one of you reading this blog about cooking up the fresh pineapple to be further used in a gelatin recipe. I will appreciate whatever kind of help and assistance you provide. Sincerely, Georgene01[[User:Georgene01|Georgene01]] ([[User talk:Georgene01|talk]]) 20:56, 28 June 2010 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==Correction== This book is coming along. However, worksheets about grammar shouldn't have grammar errors itself. On the first line of this page, you say "__ me, Jack..." The error is that "me" is in the objective case, and here it should be used as a subject ''after'' Jack and the others. So the correct version would be: __ Jack, Alice, and ''I''.
I will correct it, but "also" makes no sense. Who saw the movie before Jack, Alice, and the narrator?
I haven't seen any other page, but just a helpful suggestion: Check your grammar before putting it on the web from a reliable source (e.g. Wikipedia). Thanks and the best of luck to this book! [[User:Pkkao|Pkkao]] ([[User talk:Pkkao|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pkkao|contribs]]) 01:50, 6 August 2011 (UTC)

revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages}} == Grammar error? == This is the current point one of Uses of Nouns
1. Subject refers to the word about something is said in a sentence.

The grammar seems awkward to me. Maybe change to...
1. Subject refers to the word about which something is said in a sentence.
or perhaps simpler...
1. Subject refers to the main noun the sentence is describing. [[Special:Contributions/24.21.106.213|24.21.106.213]] ([[User talk:24.21.106.213|discuss]]) 18:15, 21 April 2011 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages}}
== Please Add Link With Every Use: ==
Dear Sir,
Very informative you are. It is humble request, please add link(which explain the use so it can easily remember or we use in future) with every use of simple present tense and with other tenses as well so we may get understand very easily or use it for long.
I really feel good to send this message and hope for the result.
Best Regards,
Muhammad Tauqeer Pakistan Lahore 0321-889184

page.title: Talk:English in Use/Typography and Document Format
Talk:False Friends of the Slavist/Map baba

revision.text: {{WikiProject Languages}} In Russian, "baba" can mean ''grandmother'' ("''баба'' Валя"), a ''woman'' ("я знаю ту ''бабу''"), kind of muffin ("ромовая ''баба''") and ''coward'' ("не будь ''бабой''!"). And we don't call an old woman "baba". "''<u>Babka</u>''" is a pejorative for an ''old woman'' that is used in Russian. So, the map is wrong.

revision.text: {{WikiProject Languages|french=yes}} ==Obscenity== I'm thinking fuck, snatch, and ass as an example of slang probably limits the intended audience of the book. [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|talk]]) 15:34, 14 November 2010 (UTC) :I suppose it is up to us to decide what to include, but probably younger readers will have already been put off by terms like "past participle" & "preposition" before they get to this section. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 20:51, 14 November 2010 (UTC) ::Kids are supposed to learn those at school from an early age, at least here in Hong Kong. (The grammar items, not the swear-words.) [[::User:Kayau|Kayau]] {{toolbar|separator=dot |[[::User talk:Kayau|talk]] |[[::Special:Emailuser/Kayau|email]] |[[::Special:Contributions/Kayau|contribs]] |[{{fullurl::Special:Log|user={{urlencode:Kayau}}}} logs] |[http://toolserver.org/~soxred93/pcount/index.php?name{{=}}{{urlencode:Kayau}}&lang{{=}}en&wiki{{=}}wikibooks count] }} 14:51, 20 November 2010 (UTC) :::That may be so, but considering the overall style of the book there has clearly been no attempt to appeal to younger readers. Also, the book does not follow any school syllabus so it is never going to be recommended by school teachers. The main contributors to the book must have been aware of this and been comfortable with it, so I see no point in changing direction now. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 17:38, 20 November 2010 (UTC)

revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages|french=yes}}
==IPA confusion== In [http://fr.wiktionary.org/wiki/connais connais] we see: /kɔ.nɛ/ and then we see (cohnay). This does really sound like how the French say it, but the IPA "ɛ" states that it should sound like the "e" in "ette" or the word "tent".
Whereas, the IPA "e" is used for the "ay" sound.
Can someone explain why IPA "ɛ" sounds like "ay" ? [[Special:Contributions/184.219.72.76|184.219.72.76]] ([[User talk:184.219.72.76|talk]]) 18:06, 31 October 2010 (UTC)
:The IPA given here is consistent with ''standard'' pronunciation from sources like Wiktionary and the Centre National de Ressources Textuelles et Lexicales [http://www.cnrtl.fr/morphologie/connais (CNRTL)] (note: E is used for "ɛ" in [[W:X-SAMPA|X-SAMPA]]), so I can't really explain the discrepancy with the approximate pronunciation "cohnay". You might expect to see "cohneh" instead, but this kind of "discrepancy" appears widely throughout the book, so we really need the author ([[User:Hagindaz|Hagindaz]]) to explain the sources used. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 20:18, 31 October 2010 (UTC)
::Thank you for commenting! As a new student, these things really trip me up, but maybe it will make me understand better as I go to various references for pronunciation. When I first saw "connais" I wanted to pronounce it like all the other "ai" words, but then saw the "ɛ" and started pronouncing it like the "e" "merci" because of this. Of course people then wrinkled their nose and plugged their ears (smile). [[Special:Contributions/68.241.76.65|68.241.76.65]] ([[User talk:68.241.76.65|talk]]) 23:12, 31 October 2010 (UTC)
:::I gave it the standard IPA pronunciation for "ɛ" as "eh" and will do this across the board. Also I will be using <sup>(n)</sup> for nasal. [[Special:Contributions/132.3.49.68|132.3.49.68]] ([[User talk:132.3.49.68|talk]]) 19:31, 3 November 2010 (UTC)
:I would be interested to know how you are mapping the IPA onto approximate pronunciations. Although I don't have a copy to hand, I believe Berlitz use something like this, but is your scheme the same as theirs? A couple of examples - would you write ''sa'' {{IPA|[sa]}} -> sah/sa or ''pâte'' {{IPA|[pɑːt]}} -> paht/pat ? [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 19:49, 3 November 2010 (UTC)
::These were from a course I took once, where the teacher liked 'oh', 'ah', 'ay', 'eh', 'ew', 'uh', 'ee', 'zh', superscript nasal notation, etc. She had "en" as 'ah<sup>(n)</sup>' and "bien" as 'bya<sup>(n)</sup>', which was the difference between IPA's 'ɑ̃' and 'ɛ̃'. Seems pretty simple to me, I don't know if others hate it allready :-) [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|talk]]) 22:06, 3 November 2010 (UTC)
::: I would do "sa" as 'sah' (ah) and "pâte" as 'paht' (ah) as they both have the same IPA 'a'. [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|talk]]) 22:16, 3 November 2010 (UTC)
:::: OK, except that "sa" contains the sound [a] and "pâte" contains the sound [ɑ] (or [ɑː], if you take account of the vowel length). Although, from the Wikipedia [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_pronunciation#Low_vowels article] on pronunciation it seems like the distinction between [a] and [ɑ] does not occur in some accents. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 23:16, 3 November 2010 (UTC)
::::: I'm still a 101 level with flash-cards (smile), but I'll read the article. My dictionary right now, is "Collins" and they have an IPA page with both [a] and [a:] on the same line, with a hint of [after, car, calm] or (ah) basically. [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|talk]]) 23:25, 3 November 2010 (UTC)
:::::: I have copied some tables from the Wikipedia article into an [[French/Appendices/Pronunciation|appendix page]] for this book, so we have somewhere to record the scheme we are using. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 23:34, 3 November 2010 (UTC)
::::::: Oh I see now, yes [a] versus [ɑ]. hmm. I look in my notes. [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|talk]]) 23:38, 3 November 2010 (UTC) {{outdent}} Well, no help, but Théâtre which has an IPA of [ɑ] shows (ah) also in my teachers notes, so both seem to be kept simple for the level. [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|talk]]) 00:19, 4 November 2010 (UTC)
: Interesting IPA stuff: [http://www.ielanguages.com/frenchphonetics.html ielanguages.com] It meantions that [ɑ] is fading from French. [[Special:Contributions/132.3.49.68|132.3.49.68]] ([[User talk:132.3.49.68|talk]]) 15:37, 4 November 2010 (UTC)

{{WikiProject Languages|french=yes}}
==Advanced Vocabulary?== For an introductory lesson, some of the vocab looks rather advanced. e.g. cancre, dizaine, huitante, nonante, octante, raconterai (future tense), septante, trentaine, vingtaine, personnage. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 19:41, 23 July 2010 (UTC) : I agree; perhaps remove some terms and simplify the dialogue. --[[User:Hagindaz|hagindaz]] 16:47, 26 July 2010 (UTC) :: Perhaps some of the words could be moved to the appendices, e.g. [[French/Vocabulary/Basic/Dates, time, and numbers]] which has a lot of overlap with this lesson. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 17:19, 26 July 2010 (UTC) ::: Good idea; I'll do so in a few days if there are no objections (or you can do so earlier). --[[User:Hagindaz|hagindaz]] 18:41, 26 July 2010 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* Vulgarity */ more about collections and print versions
revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages|french=yes}} ==Target Audience== I think it would be useful to make some statements about this, to guide any new contributors / readers. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 11:59, 22 August 2010 (UTC) #The book is aimed primarily at teenage and adult learners, who are above school leaving age. #The book is intended mainly for individual study, although nothing prevents it being used in the classroom.
: Since it's been nearly a week without any objections, you might implement this if you have time. Maybe add it to the introduction for readers, or create a guidelines page for contributors. --[[User:Hagindaz|hagindaz]] 15:09, 27 August 2010 (UTC) :: I'll put something down then. I don't think there are any changes to the lessons implied, as I see this as just reflecting the content and style of the current material. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 19:56, 27 August 2010 (UTC)
==Vulgarity== I must agree that many people would think the slang chapter is not suitable for children, but this is practically the only vulgar material. The [[Wikibooks:Collections/French|collection]] does not include this, so would be suitable for a younger audience. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 00:08, 25 March 2011 (UTC) : Aha, I didn't realize that. I thought maybe it was also in the PDF. Do you think I should roll the changes back? [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Coupe|contribs]]) 00:27, 25 March 2011 (UTC) :: P.S. I played with your book cover this afternoon. (French Book Illustration 02.jpg) I thought maybe a little flag color :-) [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Coupe|contribs]]) 00:27, 25 March 2011 (UTC) ::: RE: the description of age range, probably some intermediate form of words would be best. The slang chapter does appear in the PDF version of the print version at the moment, but not in the PDF produced by the collection. Of course it is quite easy for people to make their own collections if desired. One advantage of the print version is that it can be used as a stable "release" and you can have greater control over the layout, with new lessons starting at the top of a page and tables not being split between pages etc. At present the print version seems to be broken though, so there is probably a problem with a template somewhere. Hagindaz is the real expert on that stuff, so hopefully he will look it over sometime. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 19:43, 25 March 2011 (UTC)

revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages|french=yes}}
==Relationship with Wikitravel French phrase book== The Wikitravel [http://wikitravel.org/en/French_phrasebook phrase book] is related to this one, with material being copied both ways. Currently, this page is more focussed on general purpose phrases than ones strictly related to travel. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 13:13, 13 November 2010 (UTC) :I've been led to believe that the French don't stress syllables, and yet the examples there show stress everywhere. The examples don't seem to be consistant. That is, some have (n) for nasal, and some just show an 'n'. Confusing for me. What I've tried to do across this book, was to at least follow the IPA, which is as good a starting place as any (smile). [[User:Coupe|Coupe]] ([[User talk:Coupe|talk]]) 14:10, 13 November 2010 (UTC) ::As the IPA does not show stress, I think it would be difficult for us as anglophones to add it with any confidence. I see that the Lonely Planet French phrasebook has a similar system where no stress is shown, so we are not totally out on a limb by not showing it. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|talk]]) 18:09, 13 November 2010 (UTC)

/* female Breast VS Busen */ new section
/* Gender Order */ Forgot signature, so added it
revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages|german=yes}}
== Gender Order ==
The preferred order for listing grammatical gender in German instruction is MFNP: Masculine Feminine Neuter Plural.
This article (and several others here on Wikibooks) use the less desirable MNFP order: Masculine Neuter Feminine Plural. This order is moderately common in older American textbooks, and is apparently based purely on the observation that Masculine and Neuter ''sometimes'' have similar endings, as do Feminine and Plural. (Or perhaps it simply stems from the notion that Neuter should be "between" Masculine and Feminine.)
However, it is the MFNP order that is actually used and learned in Germany, and even in America all higher-level German textbooks nowadays use that order. More importantly, every German teacher with whom I have ever taken classes insists that any textbook listing the order as MNFP is simply WRONG.
Furthermore, one of the most popular mnemonics for remembering the article declensions is "RESE NESE, MRMN, SRSR" (pronounced "ree-see, nee-see, mister-man, sir-sir") -- but this mnemonic only works with the genders listed in the correct MFNP order.
Therefore, I propose that this page (and all other WikiBooks articles on German grammar) be restructured with the correct ''German'' order of genders: Masculine Feminine Neuter Plural.[[User:FireHorse|FireHorse]] ([[User talk:FireHorse|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/FireHorse|contribs]]) 08:08, 13 December 2013 (UTC)

revision.comment: moved [[Talk:German/Level I/Zu Hause Essen]] to [[Talk:German/Level I/Zu Hause essen]]: In German, only the first letter of a headline gets capitalized. All other words stay as they are.

revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages}}
== Info about Høgnorsk. ==
I translated and added a bit about the language, something I found especially important, since there were so little on Norwegian in general on here. Some could be lead to believe that Høgnorsk is the common Norwegian, which it of course is not. Norwegian of today has two written languages. Bokmål (directly translated en: Book Language is the most common one, Nynorsk (en: New Norwegian) the other. Personally, even if I am Norwegian, I have no knowledge of this (old) type of New Norwegian. For that reason, I took this info from the article about it on the Norwegian Wikipedia at no.wikipedia.org. The rest of the article reads:
På 1900-tallet ble det ført en statlig politikk som hadde til mål å føre landsmål og riksmål, senere nynorsk og bokmål, sammen til et samnorsk språk «på norsk folkemåls grunn». Offisiell nynorsk ble derfor styrt bort fra Ivar Aasens systematiske normering og i retning såkalte folkemålsformer, først med rettskrivningsreformen i 1917 og deretter med rettskrivningsreformen i 1938. Rettskrivningsreformene i 1917 og 1938 hadde til formål å tilnærme nynorsken til bokmål og østlandsk talemål. Disse reformene innebar således et brudd med den tradisjonelle, typeformbaserte nynorsknormeringen som Ivar Aasen la grunnlaget for. Med 1938-rettskrivningen ble en rekke tradisjonelle nynorskformer forbudt eller redusert til «sideformer». Mest dramatisk var trolig forbudet mot det såkalte i-målet som skilte mellom sterke og svake hunkjønssord (For eksempel «ei gryta», «gryta», «grytor», «grytone», «ei sak», «saki», «saker», «sakene» mot offisiell nynorsk «ei gryte», «gryta», «gryter», «grytene», «ei sak», «saka», «saker», «sakene»). Høgnorskmannen Gustav Indrebø karakteriserte derfor 1938-reformen mer som et «målbrigde» enn som en reform. Et annet sentralt prinsipp i høgnorsken er den såkalte sammenhengsloven. Rent konkret sier denne loven at når et ord skal bøyes, skal roten av ordet gå igjen i alle bøyningsformene. For eksempel heter det «å segja - segjer - sagde - hev sagt» der det i såkalt moderne nynorsk heiter å «å seia - seier - sa - har sagt». På denne måten får man sammenheng i bøyningen, og dessuten med andre ord som er utledet fra samme ord, som «segn» og «soge». Et annet kjent eksempel som illustrerer prinsippene i normeringen er bruken av g i ordet «ei gjenta», mot offisiell nynorsk «ei jente». Forklaringen her er at ordet gjente opphavlig er utledet fra ordet «gant» (moro), og følgelig blir uttalt med en [dʑ]-lyd og ikke [j] i enkelte dialekter. Kritikere av høgnorsksynet hevder ofte at høgnorsken er altfor fjern fra vanlig talemål til å kunne slå gjennom som et fullverdig skriftspråk. Høgnorskfolket på sin side hevder at det er Aasen-normalens typeformprinsipper som er best egnet til å avspeile det store mangfoldet av dialektvarianter som finnes i norsk talemål. Etter deres syn har tilnærmingen til såkalt folkemål i realiteten vært en selektiv tilnærming mot bestemte dialekter og dermed gjort nynorsken mindre samlende. Mens målfolk flest har samlet seg bak parolen om «Snakk dialekt, skriv nynorsk», har ledende høgnorskfolk dessuten tatt til ord for at nynorsk på samme måten som bokmål må etableres med et eget normaltalemål og dermed bli normdannende. Siden den høgnorske nynorsken er basert på Aasen-normalen, assosieres den ofte med Vestlandet og Telemark av utenforstående. Det er vanskelig å si noe sikkert om hvor mange som faktisk bruker høgnorsk til vanlig eller om høgnorskbrukere skiller seg fra andre nynorsk<nonwiki>brukere</nonwiki> med hensyn til f.eks. kjønn, alder, utdanning osv.
At this time, I can't go on translating the rest (or the parts which seems sensible to include in the "about" section I added to the article), but I chose to paste it here, so that others who can, can translate and add it if they can. Maybe I'll be back later too.
Also, I think it would have been best if all the names of persons had links to articles on Wikipedia about them, but I don't know how to add such links here. Maybe somebody else can do it?
Thanks! :Hi there! I added the links you requested and made a few small changes to the formatting. I am looking forward to your lessons on the dialect. If you need any other help, you can contact me here or on my own [[User talk:Thereen|talk page]].--[[User:Thereen|Thereen]] ([[User talk:Thereen|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Thereen|contribs]]) 01:58, 20 June 2011 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* Paper 1 and Paper 2? Not this year. */ new section
revision.text:
{{WikiProject Languages}}
== Paper 1 and Paper 2? Not this year. ==
I am currently enrolled in IB English HL 1 for the 2011-2012 school year. I will be a second year HL English student this upcoming school year, as I finish my high school career. While I understand there has always been the requirement of two WL Papers, the new IB standards instead require an oral reflection (a 300-500 word paper reflecting on an interactive oral presented by a portion of the class) and a single world literature paper, to be written over the same work of literature as covered in the oral presentation. This would be a complete page reformat and felt it best to bring it up in a discussion rather than try to begin this on my own, as I am not a seasoned editor of pages.
- Wade
